column1: San Juan Capistrano (; Spanish: [saŋ ˈxwaŋ kapisˈtɾano]; Spanish for '"Saint John of Capestrano"') is a city in Orange County
column2: California
column3: United States. The current Office of Management and Budget metropolitan designation for San Juan Capistrano and the Orange County area is Santa Ana–Anaheim–Irvine

column1: San Juan Capistrano is the site of a Catholic mission for which it is named
column2: Mission San Juan Capistrano. When the Mission was founded in 1776
column3: the region was populated by the Acjachemen band of Native Americans
column4: called Juaneños by the Spanish. The mission was named after Giovanni da Capistrano (1386–1456)
column6: in the Italian region of Abruzzo.

column1: The city is the site of California's oldest residential neighborhood
column2: Los Rios. It is also the home of the oldest in use building in California
column3: the Serra Chapel in the Mission. The area was the site of both the first vineyard and first winery in California.

column1: San Juan Capistrano is located in south Orange County and is bisected by Interstate 5. 33°29′58″N 117°39′42″W (33.499493
column2: -117.661614).According to the United States Census Bureau
column3: the city has a total area of 14.3 square miles (37 km2). 14.1 square miles (37 km2) of it is land and 0.1 square miles (0.26 km2) of it (1.26%) is water.

column1: The City of San Juan Capistrano employs approximately 93 people.
San Juan Capistrano is also known for its cliff swallows. The protected birds return during migration
column2: which originates in the town of Goya
column3: Argentina
column4: around St. Joseph's Day (March 19) each year. The day is celebrated by the city's annual Swallows' Day Parade and other festive events.  The swallows leave around October 23
column5: the former feast day of St. John of Capistrano. The 1940 hit song "When the Swallows Come Back to Capistrano"
column7: is a love song inspired by this annual event.

column2: the famous swallows did not return to San Juan Capistrano. They instead began migrating to and nesting in the Chino Hills of Southern California
column3: north of San Juan Capistrano. They built their mud nests in the eaves of the Vellano Country Club
column4: situated around a golf course in the Chino Hills just north of the Chino Hills State Park. Mission San Juan Capistrano officials stated that the swallows changed their route because the mission is no longer the tallest building in the area due to urban sprawl
column5: and thus stopped attracting the swallows for nesting.Realizing the city's famous birds were no longer returning home
column6: members of the Mission San Juan Capistrano enlisted the help of Dr. Charles R. Brown
column7: a cliff swallows specialist from the University of Tulsa. In 2012
column8: the first phase of a two-step process began
column9: where the sounds and calls of the cliff swallows were played throughout the mission to lure the birds back home. In 2015
column10: the project continued with the second phase where a replica wall of man-made colonies was built to give the birds a nest to return to. The nests were built to be very similar to the original nests made in the mission
column11: prior to the early 1900s re-stabilization. As of summer of 2017
column12: the cliff swallows have returned home to Mission San Juan Capistrano and are still celebrated each year at the town's annual Swallows Day Parade and Mercado Street Fair.

column2: the town celebrated its 80th annual Swallows Day Parade and Mercado Street Fair put on by the San Juan Capistrano Fiesta Association. The parade is the end celebration of a three-month Fiesta de las Golondrinas where the town puts on events to commemorate the migration home of the songbirds. The parade shuts down a portion of the downtown area to make way for floats
column3: horses
column4: and people walking in the parade. The event holds the title of being the longest-running and largest non-motorized parade west of the Mississippi.

column2: the Mission canceled its annual celebration due to the outbreak of COVID-19.

column1: San Juan Capistrano is served by Capistrano Unified School District. In the 2007–08 academic year
column2: San Juan Hills High School opened with about 600 freshman students. It is the city's only public high school. Ultimately
column3: nearly all San Juan Capistrano's high school students will move to this campus as well as some students from Capistrano Beach
column5: and southern Ladera Ranch. Residents from these other communities did not want to attend a school in San Juan on the pretense that these communities had too many differences
column6: a perspective fueled by anti-Hispanic sentiment in the whiter
column7: more affluent communities. Many residents wanted to stay at the established high schools their communities had been attending for years. While there was initially tension caused by the boundary changes implemented with the construction of the new high school
column8: it has since died down. The main relief for the tension was the construction of a connecting road from Avenida La Pata to Avenue Vista Hermosa
column9: allowing for students from San Clemente to take a more direct route to the school. The $127 million infrastructure project completed on August 13
column10: 2016.San Juan has four public elementary schools (grades K–5): Del Obispo Elementary School
column13: and San Juan Elementary School. The local public middle school (grades 6–8) is Marco Forster Middle School. Capistrano Valley High School (grades 9–12) lies just outside of the city's borders
column14: but serves many of the city's students.

column2: Junipero Serra High School
column3: also serves the area. Not to be confused with the Catholic school to the north
column4: the Serra High School is a campus dedicated to helping adults finish their pre-collegiate educational goals.

column1: San Juan also has six private
column2: non-secular schools. Capistrano Valley Christian Schools (grades pre-K – 12)
column3: Saddleback Valley Christian School (grades pre-K – 12)
column5: and JSerra Catholic High School (grades 9–12). Mission Basilica School (grades K–8) is located on the historic Mission grounds
column6: utilizes some of the historic buildings as classrooms
column7: and is part of Mission Basilica San Juan Capistrano. The other is Rancho Capistrano Christian School (grades K–8)
column8: located off Interstate 5 on Saddleback Church's south campus.

column1: The Orange County Transportation Authority (OCTA) operates bus routes within the city
column2: connecting it to other parts of Orange County.

column1: The San Juan Capistrano station is served by Amtrak and Metrolink. The station is located one block away from the historic San Juan Capistrano Mission next to Los Rios Street in downtown San Juan Capistrano. Its proximity to the city's tourist attractions makes it a popular stop during the summer months.
Interstate 5 has three interchanges completely located in the city (at Camino Capistrano
column2: SR 74/Ortega Highway
column3: and Junipero Serra Road)
column4: two interchanges partially located within the city (at SR 1/Camino las Ramblas (which is partially within Dana Point) as well as SR 73 (which is partially within Mission Viejo))
column5: and an additional northbound entrance ramp from Stonehill Drive and Camino Capistrano.

column1: Pacific Coast Highway is one of the most notable state routes in California. It officially terminates at Interstate 5 near the border between San Juan Capistrano and Dana Point. There is an official SR 1 terminus sign on a traffic light pole along the southbound lanes on SR 1 shortly after crossing under Interstate 5. It is where the northbound exit from I-5 intersects Camino las Ramblas and is within San Juan Capistrano city limits.
California State Route 73 southbound terminates at I-5 in San Juan Capistrano
column2: while the northbound direction begins at I-5. There are no exits along SR 73 in San Juan Capistrano other than its junction with Interstate 5.

column1: California State Route 74 has its official western terminus at Interstate 5 in San Juan Capistrano. The city-maintained road that continues west as Ortega Highway originally terminated at Camino Capistrano in front of Mission San Juan Capistrano; however
column2: interchange reconstruction that was completed in 2015 brought Ortega Highway to continue onto Del Obispo Street towards Dana Point
column3: with a right turn required to stay on the older portion of Ortega Highway. California State Route 241
column4: which originally terminated at Oso Parkway between Las Flores and Coto de Caza
column5: was extended roughly 4 miles to Cow Camp in the community of Rancho Mission Viejo
column6: which is located just east of the city limits.

column1: The original route of U.S. 101 ran through downtown San Juan Capistrano on what is now Camino Capistrano. It was decommissioned when Interstate 5 was completed in the 1950s.
